message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The histopathologic examination shows a neutrophil-dominated inflammation in the appendix, which is typical of acute inflammation. IL-8 is a potent chemoattractant for neutrophils and is responsible for recruiting the marked cells to the inflamed tissue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows infiltration of the appendix with neutrophils, which are attracted to the site of inflammation by chemotactic factors such as IL-8. IL-7 and IL-10 are not typically involved in the chemotaxis of neutrophils, and CCL-11 is primarily involved in eosinophil recruitment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows neutrophils, which are attracted to inflamed tissue by chemokine IL-8. Options A, C, and D are not associated with neutrophil recruitment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The histopathologic examination suggests acute inflammation with many neutrophils present, which implies an increased level of IL-8. IL-7 is a cytokine that regulates the proliferation and differentiation of lymphocytes, while CCL-11 is involved in eosinophil recruitment. IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that downregulates immune responses. Therefore, IL-8 is responsible for attracting the marked cells to the inflamed tissue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The marked cells in the histopathologic examination are neutrophils, which are attracted by chemokines such as IL-8 to the site of inflammation. IL-7 is involved in lymphocyte development, CCL-11 is involved in eosinophil recruitment, and IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The histopathologic examination shows neutrophil infiltration, which is characteristic of acute inflammation. Among the options, only IL-8 is known for attracting neutrophils to inflamed tissues.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The histopathologic examination shows neutrophilic infiltration, which is characteristic of acute inflammation. IL-8 is a chemokine that is responsible for recruiting neutrophils to the inflamed tissue. Therefore, IL-8 is the correct answer. The other options are not involved in acute inflammation or neutrophil recruitment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The histopathologic examination shows marked infiltration of neutrophils, which are attracted to the inflamed tissue by the chemokine IL-8. IL-7 and IL-10 are involved in the immune response but are not specific to neutrophil attraction. CCL-11 is a chemokine that attracts eosinophils, not neutrophils.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The histopathologic examination shows marked infiltration of neutrophils in the appendix, which suggests an acute inflammatory response. Among the options, only IL-8 is known to be involved in attracting neutrophils to sites of inflammation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The histopathologic examination shows neutrophilic infiltration, which is characteristic of acute inflammation. IL-8 is a chemotactic cytokine that attracts neutrophils to the site of inflammation, making it the most likely choice. IL-7 is involved in T cell differentiation, while CCL-11 is involved in eosinophil recruitment, neither of which are relevant to acute appendicitis. IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine, which may be involved in the resolution of inflammation, but it does not attract neutrophils to the site of inflammation.
